instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used in the proof of concept study that aimed to assess whether hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients can be reliably measured and classified?
Output: The proof of concept study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) to assess whether hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients can be reliably measured and classified.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the proof of concept study that aimed to assess whether hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients can be reliably measured and classified?
Output: Linear discriminant analysis classification of totHB signal changes in the premotor cortex and/or posterior parietal cortex was used in the proof of concept study.

instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in terms of classifying the hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients?
Output: The metric chosen in the related study was the total hemoglobin (totHB) signal changes in the premotor cortex and/or posterior parietal cortex. This metric was used to classify the hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients. The results of the study indicated that linear discriminant analysis classification of totHB signal changes showed above chance accuracy in discriminating paretic from nonparetic movement preparation trials in most of the tested patients. Therefore, this metric was able to successfully classify the hemodynamic signals associated with lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the proof of concept study that aimed to assess whether hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients can be reliably measured and classified?
Output: Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Hidden Markov Model (HMM) were used in the proof of concept study.

instruction: Can functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) reliably measure and classify hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients, based on the specific hemodynamic changes associated with left and right hip movement preparation observed in this study?
Output: Yes, based on the results of this proof of concept study, functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) was able to reliably measure and classify hemodynamic signals underlying lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients. The study found that specific hemodynamic changes associated with left and right hip movement preparation could be measured with fNIRS. Additionally, linear discriminant analysis classification of the total hemoglobin (totHB) signal changes in the premotor cortex and/or posterior parietal cortex showed above chance accuracy in discriminating paretic from nonparetic movement preparation trials in most of the tested patients. Therefore, the study provides evidence that fNIRS can detect brain activity associated with single-trial lower limb motor preparation in stroke patients.
